caption: Figure 1: We illustrate different data generative processes with causal graphical models. The discretization process introduces new discrete variables which are denoted with a tilde (~).
description: This figure shows different causal graphical models illustrating how discretization affects conditional independence testing.  (a) shows a latent variable X2 whose discretized version X2 is observed along with X1 and X3. Existing methods test for conditional independence between X1 and X3 given X2, which is different than the actual conditional independence that should be tested (X1 and X3 given X2). (b) and (c) demonstrate similar scenarios with different configurations of latent and observed variables, highlighting that the discretization process introduces new discrete variables that can lead to inaccurate CI tests if not properly accounted for. Gray nodes represent observed variables, while white nodes represent latent variables.

caption: Figure 2: Comparison of results of Type I and Type II error (1 – power) for all three types of tested data (continuous, mixed, discrete) and different number of samples and cardinality of conditioning set. The suffix attached to a test's name denotes the cardinality of discretization; for example, "Fsherz_4" signifies the application of the Fsher-z test to data discretized into four levels. Chi-square test is only applicable for the discrete case.
description: This figure compares the Type I and Type II error rates of three different conditional independence tests (DCT, Fisher-Z, Chi-square) across various data types (continuous, mixed, discrete) and experimental settings.  The Type I error represents the probability of incorrectly rejecting the null hypothesis when it is true (false positive), while the Type II error represents the probability of incorrectly failing to reject the null hypothesis when it is false (false negative). The plots show how these error rates change with the number of samples used and the size of the conditioning set.  The suffix numbers on the Fisher-Z tests indicate the number of levels of discretization applied to the data.
section: 3.1 On the Effect of the Cardinality of Conditioning Set and the Sample Size

caption: Figure 3: Experiment result of skeleton discovery on synthetic data for changing sample size (a) and changing number of nodes (b). Fisherz_nodis is the Fisher-z test applied to original continuous data. We evaluate F₁ (↑), Precision (↑), Recall (↑) and SHD (↓).
description: This figure displays the results of an experiment on causal discovery using synthetic data.  Two scenarios are shown: (a) a fixed number of nodes (8) with varying sample sizes, and (b) a fixed sample size (5000) with varying numbers of nodes. The performance of the proposed DCT method is compared to three other methods: Fisher-Z (applied to discretized data), Fisher-Z (applied to original continuous data), and Chi-square. The metrics used to evaluate performance are F1 score, precision, recall, and SHD (structural Hamming distance). The upward-pointing arrows (↑) indicate that higher values are better for F1 score, precision, and recall, while the downward-pointing arrow (↓) indicates that lower values are better for SHD.

caption: Figure 3: Experiment result of skeleton discovery on synthetic data for changing sample size (a) and changing number of nodes (b). Fisherz_nodis is the Fisher-z test applied to original continuous data. We evaluate F₁ (↑), Precision (↑), Recall (↑) and SHD (↓).
description: This figure displays the results of an experiment on causal structure discovery using two different settings. In the first setting (a), the number of nodes is fixed at 8, while the sample size varies (500, 1000, 5000, 10000). In the second setting (b), the sample size is fixed at 5000 and the number of nodes changes (4, 6, 8, 10). The results are evaluated using F1 score, precision, recall, and structural Hamming distance (SHD). The performance of the proposed method (DCT) is compared to Fisher's Z-test (applied to both discretized and original continuous data) and the chi-square test. The upward-pointing arrows indicate that higher values are better, while the downward-pointing arrow indicates that lower values are better for SHD.

caption: Figure 2: Comparison of results of Type I and Type II error (1 – power) for all three types of tested data (continuous, mixed, discrete) and different number of samples and cardinality of conditioning set. The suffix attached to a test's name denotes the cardinality of discretization; for example, "Fsherz_4" signifies the application of the Fsher-z test to data discretized into four levels. Chi-square test is only applicable for the discrete case.
description: This figure compares the Type I and Type II error rates of three different conditional independence tests (DCT, Fisher-Z, and Chi-square) across various experimental settings. The settings include three types of data (continuous, mixed (continuous and discrete), and discrete), different sample sizes, and different cardinalities of the conditioning set.  The goal is to show the impact of discretization on the accuracy of these tests and to demonstrate the advantages of the proposed DCT method, particularly in the presence of discretization.
section: 3.1 On the Effect of the Cardinality of Conditioning Set and the Sample Size

caption: Figure 5: Experiment result of skeleton discovery on synthetic data for changing sample size (a) and changing number of nodes (b). Fisherz_nodis is the Fisher-z test applied to original continuous data. We evaluate F₁ (↑), Precision (↑), Recall (↑) and SHD (↓).
description: This figure displays the performance of the proposed DCT method compared to Fisher-Z test and Chi-square test for skeleton discovery on synthetic datasets.  The top row shows results with a fixed number of nodes (8) but varying sample sizes, while the bottom row shows results with a fixed sample size (5000) but varying the number of nodes.  The metrics evaluated are F1-score, Precision, Recall, and SHD (Structural Hamming Distance).  Fisherz_nodis represents the Fisher-Z test applied to the original continuous data before discretization, serving as a baseline.

caption: Figure 7: Experimental comparison of causal discovery on synthetic datasets for denser graphs with p = 8, n = 10000 and edges varying p + 2, p + 4, p + 6. We evaluate F₁ (↑), Precision (↑), Recall (↑) and SHD (↓) on both skeleton and DAG.
description: This figure compares the performance of three conditional independence (CI) tests (Chi-square, DCT, Fisher-Z) on causal discovery tasks using synthetic datasets. The experiments vary the number of edges in the graph while keeping the number of nodes and samples constant.  The results are presented in terms of F1 score, precision, recall, and structural Hamming distance (SHD) for both the skeleton (undirected graph) and directed acyclic graph (DAG). The goal is to assess how well each test performs under different graph densities.

caption: Figure 2: Comparison of results of Type I and Type II error (1 – power) for all three types of tested data (continuous, mixed, discrete) and different number of samples and cardinality of conditioning set. The suffix attached to a test's name denotes the cardinality of discretization; for example, "Fsherz_4" signifies the application of the Fsher-z test to data discretized into four levels. Chi-square test is only applicable for the discrete case.
description: This figure compares the Type I and Type II error rates of three different conditional independence tests (DCT, Fisher-Z, Chi-square) across various data types (continuous, mixed, discrete) and experimental conditions (varying sample sizes and cardinalities of the conditioning sets). The goal is to evaluate the performance and robustness of each test under different scenarios.

caption: Figure 1: We illustrate different data generative processes with causal graphical models. The discretization process introduces new discrete variables which are denoted with a tilde (~).
description: This figure illustrates different scenarios of data generation using causal graphical models.  The key difference between the scenarios is the presence or absence of latent variables (unobserved) and the discretization process.  (a) shows a latent variable X2 that is discretized into X2. (b) and (c) demonstrate other scenarios involving discretization impacting the relationships between the variables. The purpose of this figure is to highlight how existing conditional independence (CI) tests, which assume directly observed variables, can lead to incorrect conclusions when discretization is present. The discretized variables are indicated by the tilde (~).
